{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3579192,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-03T15:28:51.498Z","cooked":"

I apologize in advance for the rehash; I’ve read the centithread on command practices, but I’m still not really sure we’re doing the right thing.

This season, our subsystems include profiled feedback controllers. Actuation is from the subsystem “set” method (not “periodic”) so there always needs to be a running command. I prefer this actuation style because it avoids a little bit of delay, it seems safer, and it makes it more clear where the goals are coming from. Commands exist largely to provide goals, so they’re pretty simple, and they’re assembled in various nested groups. The structure of the groups is effectively the behavior spec.

A common coordination pattern this season is to run two or three commands in parallel, forever, and terminate the group when both have reached some end state. For example, raise the elevator and extend the arm, and terminate when both are done. We don’t want either of the individual commands to actually terminate early, because of the actuation mentioned above: there needs to be a running command to hold position.

We could handle this coordination with a single command that actuates both subsystems, but we kinda like the separation and the smallness of the components: we can tune each thing separately more easily.

Anyway, one of our students came up with a way to handle this coordination requirement by creating a “supervisor” command whose lifespan is the conjunction of boolean suppliers from each of the “worker” commands. The supervisor is used as the deadline command in a parallel deadline group.

Is this the cleanest way to do it? What’s a better way to do it?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-04-03T15:28:51.498Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":148,"readers_count":147,"score":74.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":497923,"topic_slug":"command-coordination","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/command-coordination/497923/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3579198,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-03T15:34:38.535Z","cooked":"

In general I advise just defining nonterminating versions of your commands first and then decorating those to terminate when needed, as needed. If a certain end condition starts showing up a whole lot, write another factory that sugars the decoration for you.

If you have a nonterminating factory available this seems to be moot; there’s no need to work around undesired end conditions that aren’t there in the first place.

In short: don’t destructure commands/ignore end conditions unless you really have to (e.g. the command is provided by an external library whose source you don’t control).

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-04-03T16:23:34.113Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":124,"readers_count":123,"score":29.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":497923,"topic_slug":"command-coordination","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/command-coordination/497923/2","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3579216,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-03T15:55:43.071Z","cooked":"

ok, thanks. I think you mean something like:

Commands.parallel(arm.out(), elevator.up()).until(arm.happy().and(elevator.happy());

which looks to me like it will do the same thing I’m suggesting (in terms of command instantiation and interaction with the scheduler), just in the “fluent” style.

is that right?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-04-03T15:55:43.071Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":108,"readers_count":107,"score":41.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":497923,"topic_slug":"command-coordination","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/command-coordination/497923/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3579219,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-03T16:02:02.294Z","cooked":"

Yep. It’s up to preference whether you use the trigger compositors or just write a lambda function.

PS it is generally safe to static import the Commands class so that you don’t have to qualify the factory function names. If you’re in Subsystem scope, the Subsytem factories are local and will have naming priority when the factories overlap.

oh actually there is one difference here, which is that the snippet above puts the “happy” domain in the subsystems, but our current thing puts it in the commands, sort of parallel to isFinished, and that makes the wiring more verbose.

I think the happy domain is always as simple as “measurement within tolerance of goal” so using the subsystems for the predicates should be fine?

but it does preclude the pattern I’d kinda like to adopt in the future, which moves the profiles to the commands, so the subsystems wouldn’t know the goal at all. in that case, is there a fluent way to express it?

var up = elevator.up();
var out = arm.out();
parallel(up, out).until(() -> up.happy() && out.happy());

?

@yesiconcur this is for you.
